comments.commentBody: How about Eisenhower? He had the armistice signed and never reached a peace treaty.
Gee, I think you left out GWB!  Oh, that's right!  He was too busy going to war in a non-threatening situation to notice Korea.

One final word re the good people who disagreed with my post.

If So Korea or Japan had any guts re their defense and not act in a wimpy why hiding behind America's military shield that should put China on notice that if they don't defang their puppet North Korea re nukes, that they will both start a limited nuclear program to counter No Korea.

That will scare the heck out of China and give them impetus to de nuke North Korea...
America could not counter a North K invasion by conventional means, it would be up to South K to repel while the US would supply logistics and conventional weaponry.

Reunification is the answer, with the South leading the way (or picking up the pieces, if that be the appropriate phrase). China's pivot to the South has created untold wealth for the Chinese. The same would happen for N. Korea if they shed their Stalinist dictatorship and joined the South. Korean families, North and South, would be joined together once again. What accommodation with the Kim Jong-il family must be made to do this? I.m sure Chinese, American, and Korean diplomats, working together, could figure this out.

The nuclear weapons are a threat to everyone. One way or another, they have to go. It is in everyone's self-interest, especially N. Korea's. Long term peace and prosperity for the Korean people would result. How could this possibly be a bad alternative for any or all of the parties?

Dream on. Those who know NK know that the family's number one priority is. maintaininv power. You would as well suggest that Putin might turn Russia over to Germany in exchange for $100 billion.
This is not the way things work in Korea, and the sooner we accept that there's no neat solution -- the train for a nuclear-free N Korea left some time ago -- the sooner we Dan d envelop a rational policy. See the discussions that Plowshares sponsors on this

Don't worry. Donald Trump will show his strongest talent as President of the United States of America! He will stand tall, grab his laptop and fire off tweet storm so snarky and disabling that North Korea will never be heard of again.

Rita,
The problem is that there is not "they" in North Korea. There's a "he," his name is Kim Jong-un, and he is widely--meaning world-widely--thought to be not playing with a full deck. His most recent way of punishing what he perceives as disloyal behavior is by firing anti tank missiles at those being punished, leaving not even a trace of DNA behind.

I am pro-choice, and I'd like to see the government fund abortions as well as general health care for women. But that is not the way it is under the Hyde Amendment, and the ACA proponents caved, and agreed that insurance funds would not be spent on abortions. That was wrong.

I say all that because what I say next may not be popular. Under the Hyde Amendment, the courts allow suspension of funding for any clinic that provides abortions. But the courts have offered a simple solution.. If you separately incorporate the abortion services from the health care services, keep finances separate, and provide the services in adjacent offices, funding for the clinic cannot be cut The Maine clinic and virtually all others have an easy out that protects their health clinic funding. And it baffles me why they fight this battle when they can probably get a volunteer lawyer and a volunteer accountant to take care of the paperwork and can build a wall for a few hundred bucks.

Every Planned Parenthood clinic erects this wall between abortion finances and financing for other services. I suspect the Maine clinic does too. Unfortunately, they will continue to fight this battle because several states have passed laws attempting to deny Medicaid funding to any clinic that provides abortion services, regardless of whether they separate the finances.

ObamaCare funds are being used to pay for abortions. That is yet another lie Obama told. Ostensibly, his executive order specified that if abortion was covered by insurance, the premium for abortion coverage had to be specifically broken out on the monthly billing and government funds could not be used to subsidize it. That was too much trouble, so the insurers didn't bother to breakout the charges and HHS didn't enforce it. They were too busy suing the Little Sisters.

You are absolutely correct that the women's health services clinics can continue to qualify for federal funding if they separate legally from abortion services. The reason they refuse to do so is that the federal funds are subsidizing the abortions.

Sandra H.,

Planned Parenthood is distinct from smaller providers. It is a magnet for lunatic attacks. Their funding is being challenged, not because they failed to create the wall, but because their abortion services are allegedly 94% of their business, which is flagrantly false. I stand by my view that separation works for clinics like the one in Lewiston, and they should attend to if they have not.
I initially had IDS for "spots" but the bouncer caught it.

Hand up or IDS, which I fixed with a - and a/
Hah!
This is a great piece.  So chock full of intelligent insights, it's bears re-reading.  When Pulitzers are handed out for commentary on the Trump administration, this op-ed should be in the mix.
Please tell us you are kidding. Please.

The term war on woman's health is deceiving. This phrase implies that medical options for woman across the nation are in jeopardy. Not true.    I am a woman, and with my health care coverage I can obtain birth control pills, cancer screenings, or any other treatment that I feel necessary.  Wasn't the point of the Affordable Care Act to allow people medical insurance that otherwise did not have access to it?  Proponents of the ACA boast that millions of Americans now have health insurance.  If that is the case, why the need for these clinics?   Are the benefits offered by the ACA not extended to women? If some women feel that they cannot access health insurance, maybe the question is why is the ACA failing them?  Perhaps that is an issue to be discussed.

Perhaps you missed the bit in the article where unplanned pregnancies increased in Texas by 27% in a group affected by the closing of PP clinics. Having insurance means nothing if there is not a clinic or provider to provide the care. And even with the ACA there are still plenty of uninsured people.

Planned Parenthood operates their facilities because the need is there. There is not the capacity in the rest of the health care system to accommodate the needs of the millions who rely on PP for reproductive health care.

If the law precludes any provider from even talking with an abortion provider then access is nonexistent. There are places where ACA is so limited that woman cannot afford long term contraception. PP helps resolve that issue. And then there are folks who cannot afford co-pays. My sins and I live one state apart. When my brother was laid off at age 60 he wished he lived where I did. Chris Christie's enactment of the ACA is very different than Andrew  Cuomo's

The ACA covers birth control, but I can think of two situations off of the top of my head that could require something beyond what the ACA offers.

1. A teenage girl who is seeking contraceptive services whose parents don't approve/refuse to allow her to talk to her doctor about it.
Teenagers are on their parents insurance, which is great about 99% of the time, but not great when a teen needs information or medical care that is important to them, but that their parents don't agree with. Planned Parenthood provides information and medical care for issues that some parents may refuse to acknowledge, including LGBT+ inclusive sex ed, family planning services, condoms, and oral contraceptives. They provide these at a rate that desperate teenagers can afford, and by keeping these options open, they keep teens safer and better informed.

2. Medicaid isn't universally accepted.
It sounds like you have great insurance, and that's great. But not everyone can afford to buy a marketplace plan, or has an employer plan. Medicaid is a good solution to help those who are poor get quality coverage, but it's not yet perfect. Americans on Medicaid still need a provider willing to accept their insurance, which isn't always easy because Medicaid reimbursement tends to be subpar and put a bigger financial burden on the provider. Clinics that aim to serve underserved populations accept this, and many of these clinics are specifically aimed at those populations, whereas other providers may not be.

It doesn't take much to get our image-obsessed press to swoon. Reporting on requires knowledge about the workings of the U.S. political systems that a good portion of press corps seems to lack. Waxing poetic about clever stage management lets ill-informed reporters pose as coastal sophisticates.

My Mom was as cool as a cucumber but every once in a while, well you knew you'd gone too far and you quickly realized the mistake you'd made.
I'm just wondering for how long and how far Trump is prepared to push Obama and how far Obama is prepared to be pushed. Trump is not a smart man. He actually thinks being "president" will protect him. Trump is so messed up in so many ways we need new words to describe him/all that ails him.

You are defending a person who insisted Obama wasn't born here, and who never produced evidence to back up his claim, yet now adopting the argument that there is no proof of Don's association with Russia, depsite hard evidence to the contrary.

I am continually amazed at the lengths Trump's supporters will go to defend him and his utter garbage, but I guess their desperation is just that thick.
The Russians tapped his phone, e-mail, and what else.

I wonder, John, if the silver lining to Trump might be that electorates in France and the Netherlands will be dissuaded from turning to far-right parties. Or maybe that's just wishful thinking on my part.
Exactly WHAT is it going to take for Congress to realize that he is mentally unstable and as such is a danger to the office and the country?
Have no fear: Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell will never allow it.
It's time for 25th Amendment remedies.

At one time, military aircraft were equipped to expel a cloud of foil strips, or "chaff," to fool a missile into veering off its target. Trump's tweets and shouts are his version of chaff. May the press stay riveted to the target.
I believe President Trump is on a new and a different level in conveying his positions using Twitter.

It's actually good that they are. The lede should not be about Obama, however, but rather that Trump today confirmed that he is under suspicion for criminal activity or espionage. The part about his chief counsel trying to interfere with the investigation is also juicy.

I agree with you - he is a good, decent, honest law abiding man. I was not implying that he would even consider anything illegal or scandalous, just pointing out that his opponents would look for anything they considered remotely sketchy because of his race.
Perhaps my choice of words could have been better.
Surely it is now apparent that, like his suits, the Presidency is too big for the man.

I think he just manufactures outrageous stories to distract media attention away from his most recent real scandal (this time Sessions controversy).  It totally works - check major papers, all talking about wiretapping instead of Sessions.
Trump has now jumped even farther off the deep end, something I didn't think was possible.
